quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: It's like when their fundamental functions, when their core behaviors of diet, exercise, playfulness, socialization, sleep, when those things get disrupted, it's a sign that there is something going on here that you need to take a look at.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A practical mental model: treat disruptions to core behaviors as early warning signals that require attention.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: If your sleep always sucks, if your relationships are constantly strained or frequently strained, if your physical health is failing, there's so many ways that that can be measured.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Actionable checklist of measurable indicators to monitor for burnout or declining wellbeing.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: So there's really no excuse for that to say, "Oh, I just didn't know."
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A counter to denial: the signals are observable, so the responsibility is to notice and respond.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When those are suffering or when they're really out of whack, it's undeniable that there is something that is detrimental to your wellbeing that's going on right now, and your body is telling you, "Stop. Something needs to change."
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A memorable reframe: your body provides a clear stop-signal when core functions deteriorate.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Andy was a legendary product and growth leader at Facebook, Twitter, Quora, and Wealthfront, where he was VP of Growth and VP of Product, and then President, and as you'll hear, was in line to be CEO of Wealthfront until he came to realize that this path was not right for him.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete example of career-path reassessment: even “winning” trajectories can be misaligned and worth changing.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I moved cash over from another bank and it literally took less than half an hour to set up the account and wire money over at no cost.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of reducing operational friction (fast setup + free transfer) that founders can prioritize when choosing tools/vendors.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They make you want to use the site more often, which I had never felt with another banking site.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive product principle: even “boring” admin tools can drive engagement through great UX.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I use Coda every day to wrangle my newsletter content calendar, my interview notes for podcasts, and to coordinate my sponsors.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Specific workflow example showing how consolidating planning and coordination into one system can streamline recurring work.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Coda puts data in one centralized location regardless of format, eliminating roadblocks that can slow your team down.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable operating model: centralize cross-format work artifacts to reduce handoffs and tool sprawl.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing honesty and setting episode tone
quotes.text: So I've been both looking forward to our conversation, but I've also been dreading it a little bit because I know it's going to be incredibly valuable, but I also think it's going to get very heavy, and I think it's important to get heavy sometimes, especially with the stuff we're going to be talking about, but just wanted to share that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Models setting expectations and naming emotional weight upfront to create psychological safety for a difficult but valuable conversation.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing honesty and setting episode tone
quotes.text: Yeah, and I'm looking forward to that.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Reframes “heavy” conversations as something to lean into rather than avoid, setting a tone of openness.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing honesty and setting episode tone
quotes.text: I think one of the things that has been a change for me over the last several years is that I prefer to move forward in my life being completely honest with who I am, not hiding any aspects of myself, including the stuff that in the past I'd be afraid to share.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A clear personal operating principle—radical honesty and non-concealment—that practitioners can adopt to build trust and reduce self-censorship.

quotes.topic_title: Career success alongside hidden inner struggle
quotes.text: I spent about 17 years working in the world of startups.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Grounds his perspective in a long, high-intensity career arc, making the later lessons about burnout and inner health more credible and applicable.

quotes.topic_title: Career success alongside hidden inner struggle
quotes.text: despite having built somewhat of an impressive resume, I guess you could say, I was also struggling quite a bit in terms of my emotional, psychological, and spiritual health.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Highlights the common but often hidden mismatch between external career success and internal well-being that practitioners should proactively monitor.

quotes.topic_title: Career success alongside hidden inner struggle
quotes.text: as my career reached its pinnacle, that from a professional, from a financial perspective, I was at my highest, but when it came to other aspects of my life, I was arguably at my lowest or close to my lowest.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A memorable warning that peak professional performance can coincide with personal collapse, challenging the assumption that success is holistic.

quotes.topic_title: Career success alongside hidden inner struggle
quotes.text: there was a lot that I needed to work through that was under the hood, which I eventually came to understand very, very deeply as a result of turning inward and doing a lot of work on my own path towards self-understanding and healing some deep emotional wounds.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Points to an actionable methodology—turning inward and doing sustained self-work—as a path to resolving issues that career progress won’t fix.

quotes.topic_title: Panic attacks at Twitter and burnout onset
quotes.text: It got to the point to where there were several occasions while I was at work where I could tell that I was about ready to have a breakdown of sorts, and I would just grab my laptop, throw it in my bag, and pretty quietly just walk out of the office even if it was 10:00 AM and I'd only been there for an hour or two.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A concrete example of recognizing early breakdown signals and taking immediate action to prevent escalation.

quotes.topic_title: Panic attacks at Twitter and burnout onset
quotes.text: There were some occasions in which I was set up to go and speak to the entire company during an all-hands session, and it was something where I just had to come up with an excuse and bow out of it because at the time, I was already completely overcome and overwhelmed by this near constant panic I was experiencing, but I had a really good poker face, I don't think most people could see it.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Highlights how severe burnout can be invisible externally, which can delay support and intervention.

quotes.topic_title: Panic attacks at Twitter and burnout onset
quotes.text: The first was just the slow and steady accumulation of the pressure, the stresses, the anxieties, the emotional ups and downs that came from having such a strong commitment to my career, and frankly an addiction to achievement as a way to feel good and to feel whole, but I was so focused on my work that I had slowly become the frog that was boiling in the pot, the typical analogy of you don't realize how bad things are getting because it's happening to you slowly until it happens quickly, right?
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for how burnout creeps up gradually and then suddenly becomes acute, especially when driven by achievement addiction.

quotes.topic_title: Root causes: achievement addiction and childhood trauma
quotes.text: The first was just the slow and steady accumulation of the pressure, the stresses, the anxieties, the emotional ups and downs that came from having such a strong commitment to my career, and frankly an addiction to achievement as a way to feel good and to feel whole, but I was so focused on my work that I had slowly become the frog that was boiling in the pot, the typical analogy of you don't realize how bad things are getting because it's happening to you slowly until it happens quickly, right?
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A practical mental model for burnout as gradual, compounding pressure that becomes visible only when it’s acute—useful for earlier detection and intervention.

quotes.topic_title: Root causes: achievement addiction and childhood trauma
quotes.text: What I later came to understand was that I was also starting to experience and to address old emotional pain that I'd buried for a very long time, stemming back to the death of my mom when I was 10.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Reframes burnout as not only situational stress but also resurfacing unresolved grief—important for choosing the right kind of support.

quotes.topic_title: Root causes: achievement addiction and childhood trauma
quotes.text: So my mind did what the mind of most children will do, which is it finds a way to bury it or to ignore it.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Highlights a common coping mechanism—suppression—that can later drive adult patterns and delayed emotional processing.

quotes.topic_title: Root causes: achievement addiction and childhood trauma
quotes.text: So I learned very early on that if I wanted to feel good, I needed to achieve, and that if I wanted to love myself and be considered lovable by others, I needed to achieve.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A crisp articulation of “achievement = self-worth,” a root-cause belief practitioners can look for and work to unwind.

quotes.topic_title: Root causes: achievement addiction and childhood trauma
quotes.text: So it was really two things coming together at the same time. It was the growing pressures of an escalating career within the dynamic industry, but then also, I think, the natural maturation of my mind and of adult development such that it was time for that old pain to come to the surface, and when it did, it was very disruptive and it's something that I'm still continuing to work on to this day.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Provides a two-factor causal model—career pressure plus developmental resurfacing of old pain—that can guide diagnosis and recovery planning.

quotes.topic_title: How common burnout is in tech
quotes.text: I'd say that it's a fair estimate to say that at least 50% to 60% of tech employees who have, just to give it a bit more nuance, who have been in the saddle, so to speak, for a minimum of five to seven years, they're experiencing some form of psychological and emotional distress.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Provides a concrete prevalence estimate with an experience threshold (5–7 years) that leaders can use to calibrate how widespread burnout-related distress may be.

quotes.topic_title: How common burnout is in tech
quotes.text: It may be minor enough such that they think it's just day-to-day anxiety, but it's often much more significant than people realize because, again, it creeps up on you slowly and then all of a sudden it hits you quickly.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Highlights a common misdiagnosis pattern—downplaying early symptoms—plus a “slow creep, sudden hit” dynamic that can inform earlier intervention and monitoring.

quotes.topic_title: How common burnout is in tech
quotes.text: Along the way, I've been able to connect with, at this point, hundreds of folks in the tech industry who are dealing with their own forms of burnout or their own deep existential questions that are coming to the surface and they're trying to understand them.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Signals that burnout often co-occurs with deeper meaning/identity questions, suggesting support should address more than workload and stress management.

quotes.topic_title: Walking away from peak career and hospitalization
quotes.text: Suddenly, I found myself in a position where I was making high six figures per year into early seven figures.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A concrete data point that underscores the magnitude of what he chose to walk away from.

quotes.topic_title: Walking away from peak career and hospitalization
quotes.text: Then here I was six or seven months later, again, very subconsciously driven by the desire to succeed because underneath that was the sense that I wasn't lovable unless I was succeeding.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A memorable articulation of a hidden driver (worth = achievement) that practitioners can look for in themselves or clients.

quotes.topic_title: Walking away from peak career and hospitalization
quotes.text: I had convinced myself repeatedly for so many years that everything was okay and that I could continue to put my head down and run through these walls, these professional walls and keep going, but it got to a point to where that was no longer the case.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A counter to “just push through it” culture, highlighting the moment when persistence becomes self-harm.

quotes.topic_title: Walking away from peak career and hospitalization
quotes.text: it's important for people to understand that there are formative experiences in our lives which put us in positions to where we form adaptations in order to survive, just like my attachment to achievement and how my self-worth was entirely tied up in that.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A transferable mental model: survival adaptations can shape adult behavior and identity in ways that later need re-evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Walking away from peak career and hospitalization
quotes.text: but these adaptations, if you're unaware of them and if you're unaware of the subconscious drivers that are responsible for them, they run the risk that they go too far, and that these adaptations, which were initially beneficial to you and to your life, they reverse course in a sense, and they become detrimental to your present state and your future development.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Actionable guidance: build awareness of subconscious drivers because once-helpful patterns can become liabilities over time.

quotes.topic_title: What Andy does now: advocacy, veterans, coaching
quotes.text: Now, when people ask me what I do, I say I do mental health advocacy, and I do it in a few ways.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A simple positioning framework: define your work by mission first, then enumerate the concrete channels you execute through.

quotes.topic_title: What Andy does now: advocacy, veterans, coaching
quotes.text: One is I sit on the board of a nonprofit called Heroic Hearts Project, and what we do is we raise money so that we can pay for military veterans with PTSD to get access to alternative therapies, namely psychedelic assisted psychotherapy.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A specific, actionable example of advocacy translated into a clear mechanism (fundraising) and a targeted intervention (psychedelic-assisted psychotherapy).

quotes.topic_title: What Andy does now: advocacy, veterans, coaching
quotes.text: In general, my writing and the content that I've put out is focused on the unhappy achievers, the other folks like myself who are out there, which there's quite a few of us.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A memorable audience definition that helps practitioners narrow who they serve and tailor content to a specific high-need segment.

quotes.topic_title: What Andy does now: advocacy, veterans, coaching
quotes.text: I write in order to express my personal experience because I think there's many others that can relate.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A practical content strategy: lead with lived experience to maximize resonance and usefulness for others facing similar challenges.

quotes.topic_title: Clues.Life and personalized paths to healing
quotes.text: I called it Clues Dot Life for a reason because if there's one thing that I've learned in my own personal journey, it's that given the immense heterogeneity of the human population and how we're all born unique and then we're made further unique through our own individual life experiences, the thing that's clear to me is that if somebody is going through their own struggles, at the end of the day, they have to find the philosophies, the tools, and the methods that work for them.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A personalization-first framework for mental health: treat tools as fit-to-person rather than universal prescriptions.

quotes.topic_title: Clues.Life and personalized paths to healing
quotes.text: You can read plenty of studies, you can read the books, you can listen to what others are doing, but at the end of the day, you got to personalize it to yourself.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Actionable advice to use external resources as inputs, then tailor the approach to your own situation.

quotes.topic_title: Clues.Life and personalized paths to healing
quotes.text: So that's why I called it Clues Dot Life because I'm building this library of mental health information that allows people to navigate all of this information in search of their own clues.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A methodology for discovery: organize information to help individuals find “clues” that match their lived experience.

quotes.topic_title: Four-step framework for deep personal transformation
quotes.text: I think that there are four parts, just to give it a simple general framework. Step one is it begins with suffering. These large transitions in life rarely take place in the absence of suffering.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A clear four-step framework that reframes suffering as the necessary starting condition for major change.

quotes.topic_title: Four-step framework for deep personal transformation
quotes.text: Step two is seeking the truth behind why we suffer.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to move from pain to inquiry by investigating root causes rather than treating symptoms.

quotes.topic_title: Four-step framework for deep personal transformation
quotes.text: What I have found, and that leads to step three in the process, is that once you discover the truth of your suffering, the real root cause of it and where it came from, that's when you move to step three, which is you begin to experience and to practice self-compassion and self-love because inevitably, what you discover through this process of seeking the truth is that your suffering isn't necessarily your fault.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A practical sequence: truth-seeking unlocks self-compassion by reducing shame and self-blame.

quotes.topic_title: Four-step framework for deep personal transformation
quotes.text: So me, for example, stepping away from my career, at the end of the day, I wasn't running from something, I was running back towards myself.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reframe of major life changes as self-alignment rather than avoidance.

quotes.topic_title: Four-step framework for deep personal transformation
quotes.text: When you do that, you change. Think of that as the horizontal foundation to which the rest of your external life is built. The place you choose to live, the partner you choose to have, the friends you have, the career you have, all of these things are erections on top of a foundation of identity, and that identity is what is completely rewired when somebody goes through that four-step process, and as a result, everything that's built on top of that identity, it doesn't necessarily have to change, but it might.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A memorable identity-as-foundation mental model explaining why deep inner change can cascade into external life redesign.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of change and ego resistance
quotes.text: As soon as the ego senses that something wants to challenge it and to undermine its authority, it finds a way to push it away. It finds a way to ignore it because it is a very difficult process.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A practical mental model for why change efforts fail: the ego actively deflects threats to identity, so resistance is predictable and must be designed around.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of change and ego resistance
quotes.text: I now understand what some philosophers described as death before dying. In this process of change that I've been going through, it's been the death of the old me, the death of Andy whose identity was entirely attached to succeeding, and that old Andy doesn't want to let go.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Reframes transformation as an identity “death,” explaining the emotional intensity and why it can feel existential rather than merely behavioral.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of change and ego resistance
quotes.text: This is a survival mechanism that's somewhat gone awry within the context of modern life.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A counterintuitive lens: what feels like self-sabotage is often an outdated protective mechanism, which changes how you respond to it.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of change and ego resistance
quotes.text: That's the process I've been going through is slowly but surely finding a way to take my fingers off the steering wheel and to let that old sense of self die, and then in doing so create the room for what's next, whatever that may be.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for change: release control gradually to make space for a new identity to emerge.

quotes.topic_title: Fear of change and ego resistance
quotes.text: I'm three years into the process of discovering what that will be.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A concrete example that identity change can be a multi-year process, setting realistic expectations for practitioners.

quotes.topic_title: How to seek truth: therapy and journaling practices
quotes.text: So there is necessary suffering in life or the mandatory suffering, and then there's the unnecessary suffering, which is the suffering that is almost entirely, and I think the argument could be made that it's entirely made up in our minds.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Introduces a practical framework for separating unavoidable pain from self-generated suffering you can work to reduce.

quotes.topic_title: How to seek truth: therapy and journaling practices
quotes.text: I think if there's a goal or objective, it's to minimize the unnecessary suffering, but the seeking of the truth part is very difficult. It takes years.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Sets realistic expectations and a clear objective for truth-seeking work: reduce avoidable suffering over a long horizon.

quotes.topic_title: How to seek truth: therapy and journaling practices
quotes.text: Commonly in the West, the first step that makes a lot of sense is you turn to somebody who's trained in helping you figure out what those truths are, which is a therapist or a psychologist or a psychiatrist or a counselor.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Gives a concrete first step for practitioners: enlist trained help to accelerate insight and avoid going it alone.

quotes.topic_title: How to seek truth: therapy and journaling practices
quotes.text: It's like speed dating at first because I would argue that the most important factor is that you feel safe.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Offers a memorable heuristic for selecting a therapist: iterate quickly and prioritize felt safety above all.

quotes.topic_title: How to seek truth: therapy and journaling practices
quotes.text: I would also say, this one's a little controversial, but you're going to want a therapist that is at least as intelligent, if not more intelligent than you because I think part of that openness to learning from them and to feeling somewhat comfortable but also feeling inspired and looking forward to it as if sometimes they say things that make you say, "Oh, shit. Wow. Wow, I never thought of that. That was smart," or, "That was a wonderful insight."
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A counterintuitive selection criterion: intellectual respect can be essential for receptivity and progress in therapy.

quotes.topic_title: Recognizing when it’s more than normal stress
quotes.text: It's like when their fundamental functions, when their core behaviors of diet, exercise, playfulness, socialization, sleep, when those things get disrupted, it's a sign that there is something going on here that you need to take a look at.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A practical diagnostic framework: treat disruptions in core behaviors as a red-alarm signal, not “normal stress.”

quotes.topic_title: Recognizing when it’s more than normal stress
quotes.text: When those are suffering or when they're really out of whack, it's undeniable that there is something that is detrimental to your wellbeing that's going on right now, and your body is telling you, "Stop. Something needs to change."
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A clear action trigger: if fundamentals are breaking down, interpret it as an urgent signal to change course.

quotes.topic_title: Recognizing when it’s more than normal stress
quotes.text: Reflecting on my own situation, I almost had a heart attack at 35, and I got the classic talk from a Stanford cardiologist saying, "You're just going to be another 40-something-year-old CEO with a broken heart."
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A vivid personal example showing how chronic stress can escalate into acute, life-threatening health events.

quotes.topic_title: Recognizing when it’s more than normal stress
quotes.text: The years of really poor sleep, the number of teeth that I had broken that I had to have fixed multiple times because for years my grinding was so bad that I had to, now two times over, had to completely redo all the teeth, all my molars, and then most of the front teeth as well, and I just continued to move forward even though my body was, again, throwing out all the signals.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Concrete physical symptoms (sleep and teeth grinding) as measurable indicators that stress has crossed into bodily breakdown.

quotes.topic_title: Recognizing when it’s more than normal stress
quotes.text: Hey, when mental health presents itself, look to the body because it's the body that is keeping the score.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A memorable mental model that reframes mental health as something you can often detect through physical signals first.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The best way to see what Miro is all about and how it can help your team collaborate better is not to listen to me talk about it, but to go check it out for yourself.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable go-to-market advice: prioritize hands-on product experience over marketing explanations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: With the help of the Miro team, I created a super cool Miro board with two of my own favorite templates, my one pager template and my managing up template that you can plug and play and start using immediately with your team.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Concrete example of accelerating adoption by providing ready-to-use templates teams can apply immediately.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Miro is a killer tool for brainstorming with your team, laying out your strategy, sharing user research findings, capturing ideas, giving feedback on wireframes, and generally just collaborating with your colleagues.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Practical checklist of high-value collaboration use cases practitioners can map directly to their workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We've talked about the suffering step, then the understanding the truth of what is going on.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a step-based process that frames progress as moving from pain to clarity before action.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The next step is self-compassion and recognizing that it's not your fault.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Actionable personal-development guidance: explicitly add self-compassion as a distinct step after insight.

quotes.topic_title: Building self-compassion through daily rewiring
quotes.text: It's going to take time to rewire that because what you're effectively trying to do is take an internal narrative and edit and rewrite that thing, and this internal narrative is probably at a foothold in you for years or decades. So it's reasonable to believe or to understand that, "Okay. If I have not had a high opinion of myself for 30 years, that's not going to change overnight."
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A practical mental model for self-compassion as long-term “rewiring” rather than a quick mindset shift, setting realistic expectations for change.

quotes.topic_title: Building self-compassion through daily rewiring
quotes.text: with truth is the awareness, "Okay. I understand that I have a low sense of self-worth, and I understand that it plays out in all these ways, and I have the awareness of it that now when I'm doing something that is a conditioned behavior or a conditioned response born out of that deep self-belief or that negative core belief, then when I spot it, there's an opportunity for me to intervene," and it starts in the simple ways.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Defines an actionable loop: awareness of conditioned behavior creates an “intervention point,” emphasizing small, repeatable changes.

quotes.topic_title: Building self-compassion through daily rewiring
quotes.text: "Hey, say thank you or you're welcome. That's it. When somebody gives you a compliment, just say thanks, accept it."
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A concrete micro-practice for interrupting self-deprecating reflexes and training self-acceptance in everyday interactions.

quotes.topic_title: Building self-compassion through daily rewiring
quotes.text: If you do that consistently enough and you keep practicing it, and you keep it up every day, then you're developing a new internal narrative through all those little actions, and it accumulates in ways that are pretty powerful.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: Highlights the compounding effect of daily behavioral reps as a method for changing identity-level beliefs.

quotes.topic_title: Building self-compassion through daily rewiring
quotes.text: Looking back at that I was like, "Yeah, there I was, another desperate attempt to feel worthy," but I also recognize now that that was medicine for me, that me going out onto a remote mountain range for five hours every Saturday and just running well beyond the point of discomfort was consistently cathartic for me. I would cry at the end of almost every single one of those runs.
quotes.speaker: Andy Johns
quotes.context: A vivid example showing how “extreme” practices can be both a coping strategy and a healing modality, reframing endurance challenges as emotional processing.
